awd_titl_txt: NSF Summer 2019 workshop: Computing Arctic Data: Orono, ME - Spring 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
To better understand causes, trends and thresholds of a changing Arctic and to develop robust societal adaptation strategies new research tools are needed. There is a wealth of past climate data sets stored in the NSF-funded Arctic Data Center (ADC) that are unresolved yet have the potential to expand and deepen the current state of understanding about how the Arctic is responding to environmental changes. This award supports an integrative workshop that will bring together a diverse group of early career scientists and experts from the fields of ice core, computer and climate sciences to transform the existing research data computation platform. The goal is to pave the way for the development of a future generation of computer tools necessary to better understand complex interactions of multiple driving forces that are changing Earth's environment. Objectives are to evaluate the latest computational advances, break existing interdisciplinary barriers that limit the use of ice core data sets in climate research, and, by openly sharing results, promote the development of future products that will benefit the Arctic research community and the global population.
  
Evaluating present and forecasting future trends in the "New Arctic" system is closely connected to understanding multidimensional paleoclimate data archives. Using open source tools to ease the reproduction of computational and data-intensive portions of paleoclimate research, transparency in data processing steps will increase. In addition, (1) the range of usability of existing climate and ice core based paleoclimate data archives will be extended; (2) open access data and software libraries, utilizing open source based software tools will be developed; (3) paleoclimate and computer infrastructure specific white papers will be developed that will summarize the state of the problem, map future pathways for systematic improvements, and finally converge this rapidly evolving research domain with a novel computational and easy to use data processing framework.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project objective to evaluate the latest computation technology advances used by the ice core research community and identify interdisciplinary barriers and challenges that prohibit wide adaptation ice core data in Arctic climate research were addressed via a series of in-person community driven workshops, online presentations and shared www resources. The first Arctic Data Workshop was held May 14-17, 2019 at the University of Maine (UMaine), Orono, ME. It brought together 24 early career researchers, data scientists, and graduate students working with Arctic ice core data sets. Participants represented various US ice core research groups and had been focused on evaluation and testing tools to simplify the use of publicly available Arctic data in a meaningful way. Community input received during the workshop documented best practices and experiences of scientists with incorporating and sharing computer code development, digital data curation, and software engineering. Due to COVID-19, the follow-up workshop planned in-person in Alexandria, Virginia on May 3, 2020 for the broader ice core community was canceled but key first workshop outcomes and recommendations on data sharing were presented to the ice core community during the Ice Core Science Community Planning Workshop on April 3, 2020 that was organized by the U.S. Ice Drilling Program (IDP).

Two additional in-person workshops took place on June 1, 2022 at the NSF Ice Core Facility, Denver, CO and UMaine on August 1-2, 2022, with 13 and 10 participants respectively. These two workshops focused on refining ice core sampling and documentation strategies and providing ice core community recommendations for adaptating the IGSN numbering at the NSF Ice Core Facility, and standardizing ice core measurements submitted to national data centers.

Workshops evaluated the current state of cyberinfrastructure needs for the ice core community and began to address the most pressing issues of standardization of high-quality data collection, discussed mechanisms of developing and adapting best practices for ice core data sharing. Workshops contributed to building an ice core community, provided inclusive networking opportunities to new and young investigators, and educated participants on the availability of computer tools for finding and retrieving ice core data from ice core data repositories. 

Project activities guided the career development of several early career investigators. For example, one Earth Sciences graduate student involved with the project is currently a data scientist working on open-source data initiatives. A Computer Science graduate student now has a faculty position and continues research in data management.

The project initiated several data repositories related to ice cores.
